incidents.name: Elevater rates of errors for Help Center

incident_updates.body: Between 2023-10-20 0215 UTC and 0327 UTC, customers would have experienced elevated error rates and high latency when accessing Help Centers. This issue is now resolved, and all services are working as expected.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are currently investigating reports of customer Help Centers showing elevated error rates and higher latency than normal.

incidents.name: Delays in updates for user and company data.

incident_updates.body: Between 2023-18-10 0900 UTC and 1100 UTC, we experienced a delay in updates for user and company data, which may have resulted in message matching delays for Email sending, user list and segments being outdated, and API features such as Search return stale results. We are now backfilling user and company updates made during this time. This issue is now resolved, and all services are working as expected.

incidents.name: Issues with delays in assigning conversations

incident_updates.body: We have fixed an issue where customers would have experienced delays in conversations appearing in Inboxes after assignment, and would only appear after a page refresh. This issue is now resolved and all services are working as expected.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
We continue to investigate here, and will update soon with more information.
We are continuing to investigate reports of delays in conversations being assigned in the Inbox.
We are currently investigating an issue where customers are experiencing delays in conversations being assigned in the Inbox.

incidents.name: Slowness in the Intercom inbox

incident_updates.body:
**Root Cause Analysis:** Database proxy service took Intercom down

Brian Scanlan, Senior Principal Systems Engineer

Oct 13, 2023

# Summary

Over the last few months, Intercom has been rolling out an updated proxy service for MySQL. There have been two large outages as a result - we are discontinuing the project and have rolled back to the setup in place before August 2023. The two outages have both been relatively complex "[metastable](https://www.usenix.org/publications/loginonline/metastable-failures-wild)" events involving interactions between thousands of clients, multiple layers of proxies and the behavior of the RDS Aurora MySQL service, and the proxy service getting into an unrecoverable state. Both outages caused an unacceptably high impact to our customers as well as to our own use of Intercom. We are still in the process of understanding the nature of exactly how ProxySQL 2 gets into an unrecoverable state, but we want to quickly share the background and details of what happened, and we may update this document over time.

# Background

‌

Intercom's is primarily served by a large Ruby on Rails monolith application. We regularly have 50,000 Rails processes running on over 1000 EC2 hosts each day serving customer requests and processing background work. The primary datastore of the Ruby on Rails application is MySQL. The application connects to 13 AWS RDS Aurora MySQL clusters, which are sharded using a mix of functional and per-customer workspace basis. One of the problems of this architecture is connection management on MySQL hosts. There are limits on the maximum number of connections that can be opened to any individual MySQL host, and on AWS RDS Aurora the limit is [16,000 connections](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonRDS/latest/AuroraUserGuide/AuroraMySQL.Managing.Performance.html). As each running Ruby on Rails process generally needs to connect to each database cluster, this limit is something we had to engineer a solution for. On most of the MySQL clusters, the read traffic is sent by the Ruby on Rails application to read-replicas, which spreads the connections out over a number of hosts, in addition to horizontally scaling the query load balancing across the read-replicas. However for write requests to work well, we need to use a different approach and in 2017 we rolled out ProxySQL to put in front of the primary writer nodes in each MySQL cluster. ProxySQL maintains a connection pool to each writer in the MySQL clusters and efficiently re-uses connections to serve write requests made by our Ruby on Rails application. Our operational experience with ProxySQL since has generally been good, and we have built a good working relationship with the ProxySQL developers.

‌

ProxySQL 2 was released a few years ago, and one of the new features is a [far better integration](https://proxysql.com/documentation/aws-aurora-configuration/) with AWS RDS Aurora MySQL clusters. These new features can improve reliability through faster failover and recovery times, as well as now being suitable for putting in place of the reader nodes in each cluster, which would allow for a scaledown of the number of readers running in each cluster. We attempted a limited rollout of ProxySQL 2 in mid-2022, however we ran into some edge case bugs, and we worked with the ProxySQL developers on getting them fixed. Because of how critical ProxySQL is on the serving path for the Intercom application, we were cautious about the rollout and were happy to wait for bugs to be fixed.

‌

‌

# August 23rd 2023 outage

‌

We started using ProxySQL 2 in production on August 8th 2023. We did a controlled, gradual rollout where we moved traffic incrementally over on a per-MySQL cluster basis over a number of weeks. On the morning of August 23rd we moved another large cluster over to ProxySQL 2 without issue. However, around the time of our daily peak traffic on that day at 15:01 UTC, we started to get alerts for high latencies on the Intercom application. Within a minute we had identified that it was related to the serving of MySQL requests and began working on the problem, following our standard incident management process. At 15:09 the situation degraded further, with errors and high latencies widespread, making Intercom unusable. At this point we had identified DNS resolution errors occurring on the ProxySQL 2 fleet as a likely cause. An attempt was made at 15:13 to remove ProxySQL 2 from service by using a feature flag to revert to the prior configuration, however this then caused a large number of additional connections to be opened to the MySQL clusters and connection counts reached their maximum on the largest database cluster, and so we reverted back to using ProxySQL 2 at 15:18. Latencies and errors recovered at this time, but we were without a safe rollback plan and with ProxySQL 2 service back serving requests. By 15:20, an autoscaling rule in place on the largest database cluster had added two additional read replicas into the cluster as a result of the high connection count on the read nodes of the cluster.

‌

A few minutes later at 15:34, MySQL query latency and error rates started degrading again due to DNS resolution failures on the ProxySQL 2 fleet. We took two different actions at this point - scaling up the ProxySQL 2 fleet, and scaling down the fleet serving the Intercom web application. The Intercom web application had aggressively scaled up in response to the elevated latencies, a tactic that has worked well in our environment in the past, however we had recently changed this scale-up to be very aggressive for the web serving fleet. By 15:45, additional ProxySQL 2 hosts were in service and latencies started to improve, however we were still uncomfortable with leaving ProxySQL 2 in service. We made an assessment of the capacity of the largest database cluster since it had scaled up, and again switched off use of ProxySQL 2 at 15:52, this time without any problems due to the additional read replicas being now in place.

‌

# October 12th 2023 outage

‌

After the previous outage, we followed our incident review process and completed the actions we had identified in this process, including rolling out robust DNS caching on each host, running a larger ProxySQL 2 fleet on smaller hosts and testing various traffic loads on the fleet. We again started using ProxySQL 2 in production on September 4th 2023 with no issues with all MySQL clusters using it.

‌

On October 12th 2023 at 13:56:42 UTC, a deployment went out to the Ruby on Rails application containing an expensive MySQL query on the MainDB MySQL cluster. The overall load increase was small - around 6% or so, along with a similar increase in network throughput, as the query was sending a lot of data back to the Ruby on Rails application. We consider this to be a trigger for the outage due to the timing of this bad query rolling out.  At 14:00 UTC latency started rising on the Ruby on Rails application. A number of throughput metrics on the MainDB cluster started slowly dropping including select rate and network bandwidth utilized, and the number of connections opened to each read-replica started to slowly increase, however overall database load and CPU metrics were stable.  At 14:05 the first paging alarm fired for high frontend latency. The oncall engineer acknowledged the alarm within a minute, and by 14:07 UTC had established that the problem was related to queries to the reader nodes of the MainDB MySQL cluster, and initiated our incident command process. The first statuspage update was published at 14:10 UTC. At this time the Intercom application was mostly slow, with a small number of errors being reported.

‌

This all changed at 14:11 UTC, when ProxySQL health checks for the read-replicas started failing and there were a large number of login failures. Each ProxySQL host monitors the health of each database it uses in order to maximize health and availability of the service. As a result of the health check failures, all but one of the read-replicas were now serving very little traffic, and due to high latencies and error rates in queries, the Intercom application was now fully down. We brought in subject matter experts in ProxySQL and MySQL and started to troubleshoot the problem.

‌

We tried a number of things based on our understanding of the previous outage - we rolled back deployments, scaled up the ProxySQL fleet, shedded load by scaling down parts of the Intercom application, and scaled up the read-replicas. By 14:48 we had partial recovery with near-full throughput levels of throughput going through the read-replicas, but there was still a high latencies and errors on the application, along with ongoing login failures to the read-replicas and we weren't confident in the stability of the service. Connectivity to the cluster overall was inconsistent across different ProxySQL 2 nodes and we observed error messages indicating loss of Aurora cluster topology state. At 15:04, throughput through the read-replicas collapsed entirely after we applied a configuration intended to hardcode the cluster topology into the ProxySQL 2 configuration, and we had difficulty connecting directly to the databases. While we had stabilized the health-check related instability, the underlying issue around ProxySQL 2 not being able to maintain a healthy set of connections to the read-replicas was still present. We decided to go back to the architecture that was in place in early August, removing ProxySQL 2 entirely from our environment. The decision to roll back the architecture change was made at 15:10 UTC, but as the feature flag change had to be done directly on the database due to the outage, this was completed at 15:20 UTC, and immediate recovery followed.

## What went right

* Our detection and general operational response was fast. We had the right people involved within minutes, and narrowed down the problem quickly.

## What could be better

* We tried to troubleshoot and work around the problem, when we could have rolled back to the previous architecture sooner. The architectural rollback itself caused problems in the August outage, as it requires a scale-up of read-replica nodes across many MySQL clusters, which can take between 15-20 minutes. The partial recovery encouraged us to keep going with the recovery efforts.
* The ProxySQL 2 rollout has impacted our availability badly twice despite availability improvements being a goal of this work. We will focus on evolving our MySQL architecture to remove the need for proxies entirely and simplifying our setup.

# Actions

1. Investigate further how ProxySQL 2 got into an unrecoverable situation. If useful, we will report the details to the maintainers of ProxySQL.
2. We will work on future simplification of our MySQL platform, such as moving to next generation MySQL management systems like [Vitess](https://vitess.io/) which remove the need to run proxies.
3. We will ensure that future low-level infrastructure changes do not use feature flags that require the application to be working well to roll forward/back.
incident_updates.custom_tweet: We published a postmortem on our October 12th incident: https://stspg.io/5h9hjl26zt80

incident_updates.body:
Between 2023-10-12 14:01 UTC and 2023-10-12 15:21 UTC, customers would have experienced high latency and elevated error rates across all Intercom features including the Inbox, Messenger and automation features such as Fin due to a database issue. We have implemented a fix for this issue, and all services are now working as expected.

Customers using Intercom workspaces hosted in our EU and Australian datacenters would not have been affected.
We are seeing full recovery and will continue to monitor our systems.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
We are continuing to work on a fix for this issue.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.
We are continuing to investigate high latencies and errors on across Intercom.
We're investigating slowness in the Intercom inbox.

incidents.name: Inbox Apps Not Functioning as Expected

incident_updates.body: We have resolved this issue, inbox app functionality is back to normal.
We have implemented a fix and are monitoring.
We have identified the root cause of this issue and we're working on a fix.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are investigating reports of issues with the functionality of our inbox apps.

incidents.name: Web App and API Degraded Performance

incident_updates.body: Fully resolved. We saw degraded performance and high latency across our web app and APIs between 27/09/2023~17.54BST and 27/09/2023~17.59BST.

incidents.name: Degradation of background services in all Intercom regions

incident_updates.body: We have reverted a bad code deploy which affected background job processing in all our regions. This error would have caused general delays and latencies across most feature of Intercom, including conversation assignment, automated support features such as Fin, Operator, and email sending. This issue is now resolved and all services are working as expected.

incident_updates.body: We are investigating issues with background worker processing of jobs affecting multiple services across all Intercom regions

incidents.name: Stale data in Users Search

incident_updates.body: At 10.50pm UTC we successfully completed processing the user data backlog, user search data is no longer stale.
At 10.50pm UTC we successfully completed processing the user data backlog, user search data is no longer stale.
At 10.50pm UTC we successfully completed processing the user data backlog, user search data is no longer stale.
Affected AWS services have recovered, we are monitoring as we start to ingest user data again.

We continue monitoring the ongoing AWS outage: https://health.aws.amazon.com/health/status

At the moment we have not detected any additional impact on our services.
We are continuing to monitor possible degraded performance across our product as AWS expanded the list of affected services: https://health.aws.amazon.com/health/status

We are monitoring an AWS outage that is causing our Users Search data, in particular data will be stale when:

- Searching for users in the Teammate app
- In User Segments in the Teammate app
- In the Matching system (ex. sending outbound messages to users that no longer match filters)
- In the Contacts API

We will update as the situation evolves.

incidents.name: Realtime Web App Degraded Performance

incident_updates.body: The realtime performance of the teammate app and Messenger was degraded between 13:25 UTC and 14:10 UTC. This is now fully resolved.
We are continuing to monitor for any further issues.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.

We are currently investigating increased error rates for the Intercom web app. This impacts the realtime feel of the teammate app.

Customers using our EU and AUS data residency regions are unaffected at this time.

components.name: Web Messenger
components.description: The Intercom messenger for web applications

components.name: Mobile Messenger

incidents.name: Partially degraded services across Intercom US

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
We are continuing to monitor the situation. We are seeing recover across most of our services.
We have shipped a fix for this issue and are monitoring the situation as we work through a backlog of jobs.
We've identified the issue and are working on a fix
We are observing a significant delay in background jobs processing for our US data region across multiple services. We are currently investigating the root cause.

incidents.name: Multiple services in Intercom unavailable briefly

incident_updates.body: For a brief period of time our Articles, Messenger, API and Messenger Apps were partially degraded due to a bad code deploy. We have since reverted the change and are monitoring the situation.

incidents.name: Elevated Latency and Connectivity Issues with Intercom

incident_updates.body:
Between 2022-03-24 1249 UTC and 2022-03-24 1256 UTC, some customers would have experienced elevated latency issues and connectivity problems connecting to Intercom. This issue is now resolved, and all services are working as expected.

Customers using our EU and Australian Data Residency Regions would have been unaffected.

incidents.name: Increased error rates in the Intercom application

incident_updates.body: Customers would have experienced errors with loading the Intercom application, receiving HTTP 403 errors. This issue is now resolved and services are working as expected.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
We are currently investigating increased error rates for the Intercom web app. Customers using our EU and AUS data residency regions are unaffected at this time.

incidents.name: Intercom Web App slow to respond

incident_updates.body:
Between 2023-03-22 1604 UTC and 2023-03-22 1625 UTC, customers would have experienced delays and errors in loading the Inbox. This issue has been resolved and all services are now working as expected.

Customers with workspaces in our EU and AUS data residency locations would have been unaffected.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are investigating an issue with the Intercom App loading slowing for customers.

incidents.name: Issues with "Lost Connection" errors in the Inbox

incident_updates.body:
Between 2023-03-22 1456 UTC and 2023-03-22 1524 UTC, customers may have experienced errors in the Inbox regarding "Lost Connection", and the Messenger would have been delayed in sending real-time messages. This issue has been resolved, and all services are operating as normal. 

Edit: Customers may have experienced a brief short disruption again at 2023-03-22 1704 UTC. A hard refresh of your web browser should resolve any remaning issues.

Customers using our EU or Australian Data Hosting regions would have been unaffected at this time.
A fix has been implemented and we are monitoring the results.
We've identified a cause for this error, and are working on resolving the problem.
We are currently investigating an issue where customers are receiving "Lost Connection"  error messages in the Inbox. Real-time messages such as "User is typing" are also affected at this time.

incidents.name: Help Center not working for customers

incident_updates.body:
Between 2023-03-20 1703 UTC and 2023-03-20 1715 UTC, customers would have experienced the Help Center product being unavailable and not loading. This issue is now resolved, and all services are working as expected.

Customers using workspaces hosted in Intercom's EU or AUS Data Regions would have been unaffected during this time.
We've shipped a fix here and are now monitoring for impact.
We are currently investigating reports of the Help Center product not loading correctly.

incidents.name: Issues logging into app.intercom.com

incident_updates.body:
Between 2023-03-20 1255 UTC and 2023-03-20 1335 UTC customers would have experienced an issue logging into https://app.intercom.com . This issue is now resolved, and all services are working as expected.

Customers who were already logged in were not affected during this time. Customer using our EU and AUS Regional hosting were also unaffected.

We have shipped a fix for this issue, and customers are able to log in now. We're monitoring now for full resolution.

Customers who are already logged in are unaffected at this time. Customer using our EU and AUS Regional hosting are also unaffected.

We are currently investigating issue where customers are getting a "Retry Later" error when trying to login into https://app.intercom.com. 

Customers who are already logged in are not affected at this time. Customer using our EU and AUS Regional hosting are also unaffected.

incidents.name: Intercom web application not available

incident_updates.body: Between 09:16 and 09:23 UTC the Intercom web application was down. We've taken action to resolve the problem.

incidents.name: Intercom web application not loading in Safari

incident_updates.body: Between 10:41 - 11:27 UTC the Intercom web application could not load on Safari. We rolled back a change and it is now working fine.
The Intercom web application is not booting for the Safari browser. We have identified the problem and are working on rolling back a change.

incidents.name: Brief Intercom web application disruption

incident_updates.body: Between 10:44 - 10:47 the Intercom web application, including the inbox, was slow or returning errors. We identified and rolled back the change that caused this.

incidents.name: Intercom down for all workspaces hosted in the US

incident_updates.body: Between 09:22 and 09:45 UTC, Intercom workspaces and services hosted in the USA region were down. We quickly identified and rolled back a deployment that caused the problem, but needed to also reboot a database cluster to restore service. We apologise for the disruption.

affected_components.name: Intercom message delivery - Chats and Posts

incident_updates.body: We are seeing recovery of our services.

affected_components.name: Intercom message delivery - Chats and Posts

incident_updates.body: Intercom is down in the USA region. We have identified a likely cause and are currently rolling back.
